Description: Saints Anthony Abbot and Paul the Hermit in the wilderness fed by a raven, the bird in the upper left carrying bread in its beak Chiaroscuro woodcut with one brown tone block
Curator's comments: This impression is still mounted on the sheet of the album from Consul Smith's collection that was dispersed at the Bright sale in 1918 (lot 371). Formerly described as a print of St Elijah (another hermit saint fed by a raven), the subject was correctly identified by Marco Riccomini (email June 2021).
Associated names: Representation of: St Antony of Egypt
Representation of: St Paul the Hermit
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: James Franck Bright (sale Sotheby's 26/8.vi.1918/371 (four in lot))
Acquisition notes: The run of prints from 1918,0713.9 through to 73 all come from two albums of colour woodcuts formed by Consul Smith in Venice in the second quarter of the XVIIIc. They were broken up at the sale at Sotheby's 26-28 June 1918 of the collection of the Rev. James Franck Bright, DD, late Master of University College Oxford, and formerly collected by Dr Richard Bright, MD. Colnaghi acted as the BM's agent, and Dodgson put together a group of donors who presented individual prints; these were purchased outright, while the rest were exchanged for duplicates.
